PREFACE

The International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), an agency of the United Nations, seeks to
promote appropriate levels of aviation security throughout the global community. ICAO promulgates
Standards and Recommended Practices (SARPs) in respect of civil aviation security through Annex 17
of the Chicago Convention, 1944. Requirements of 12th edition of Annex 17 are reflected in this
document.

Being a signatory to the Convention on International Civil Aviation (Chicago Convention, 1944), the
Republic of India is obliged to implement the Standards and Recommended Practices (SARPs) adopted
by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) through the National Civil Aviation Security
Programme (NCASP), a policy document required by Standard 3.1.1 of Annex 17 of the Chicago
Convention which is applicable from 21 February 2024. Annex 17 further mandates each contracting
State as follows:

3.5.1 Each Contracting State shall require the appropriate authority to develop, implement and maintain
a national civil aviation security quality control programme to regularly determine compliance with and
validate the effectiveness of its national civil aviation security programme. The priorities and frequency
of oversight activities shall be determined on the basis of risk assessments carried out by the relevant
authorities, and include security audits, inspections and tests 10 provide for the rapid and effective
rectification of any deficiencies. The national civil aviation security quality control programme shall
include the following elements

@) independence of those conducting oversight from those applying measures implemented under
the national civil aviation security programme;

b) the personnel conducting oversight are trained to appropriate standards;

©) the personnel conducting oversight have the necessary authority to obtain all relevant
information to carry out these tasks and to enforce corrective actions;

d) a confidential reporting system for analysing security information provided by sources such
as passengers, crew and ground personnel: and

©) a process to record and analyse the results of the national civil aviation security quality
control programme, in order to contribute to the effective development and implementation of
the national civil aviation security programme, including idemtifying the causes.

The programme will be subject to amendment from time to time. Such amendments are to be controlled
through the records of amendments included in this document. Each entity responsible to implement the
National Civil Aviation Security Quality Control Program shall maintain an updated copy of this national
document. If any AVSEC order/ circular/ OM/ instruction, etc. mentioned in this document is amended
or superseded, the latest version of the same shall prevail

The information or part thereof contained in this document can be disseminated by only authorized
individuals, entities, or organizations. Any disclosure, dissemination, reproduction or onward distribution
to an individual. entity or organization without a “need-to-know” as defined in NCASP is prohibited and
shall attract appropriate penal action.

Introduction: 
1.1 
Objective 
1.1.1 The objective of the National Civil Aviation Security Quality Control Programme (NCASQCP) 
is to determine compliance with and validate the effectiveness of the National Civil Aviation 
Security Programme (NCASP), including all other programmes, aviation security legislative 
instruments, and any AVSEC order, circular, directive, or office memorandum mandated by the 
NCASP or Director General, BCAS. This shall be achieved through the implementation of a 
programme of security audits, inspections, tests, and exercises by BCAS and through similar 
internal quality control measures conducted by airport operators, aircraft operators, regulated 
agents, catering establishments, and other entities entrusted with civil aviation security 
responsibilities mandated in the NCASP. 
1.1.2 The NCASQCP also provides a framework to address and resolve deficiencies identified during 
quality control activities and identifies all aspects of security measures that may need changes in 
aviation security legislative instruments, AVSEC orders, circulars, directives, office 
memorandums, NCASP, etc. It is of paramount importance that entities responsible for the 
management, setting of priorities, and organization of the National Civil Aviation Quality 
Control Programme operate independently from those responsible for the implementation of 
measures under the National Civil Aviation Security Programme. 
1.1.3 A fundamental component of an aviation security system is the effective implementation of 
quality control measures. In the aviation security context, quality control measures can be defined 
as the surveillance techniques and activities used to assess the aviation security system of India 
and, where required, to resolve identified deficiencies. In order to implement quality control 
measures, Appropriate Authority of Civil Aviation Security of India shall develop, implement 
and maintain a National Civil Aviation Security Quality Control Programme (NCASQCP).  
1.1.4 Annex 17 of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) is the primary source of 
Standards and Recommended Practices (SARPs) for the establishment and management of a 
State’s national civil aviation system. The fundamental challenge for the establishment and 
management of such a civil aviation security system is to create an aviation security regime that 
is highly effective in preventing acts of unlawful interference and ensuring compliance with 
specific regulations without unduly interfering with the efficiency of civil aviation, imposing 
excessive costs or intruding unnecessarily into private rights or civil liberties.  
 
1.2 Authority to develop, maintain and oversee the NCASQCP: 
1.2.1 Director General (DG), BCAS, has authority to develop, implement, maintain, and oversee the 
NCASQCP (National Civil Aviation Security Quality Control Programme). DG BCAS also has 
the authority to review the NCASQCP to determine compliance with and validate the 
effectiveness of its National Civil Aviation Security Programme. 
 
1.2.2 The NCASQCP has been established in accordance with: 
a. ICAO Annex 17, SARPs and selected guidance materials from Aviation Security Manual 
Doc. 8973. 
b. The Aircraft Act, 1934 
c. The Aircraft (Security) Rules, 2023 
d. The NCASP, Republic of India.

of the Aircraft (Security) Rules, 2023. 
 
1.2.4 The National inspector / auditor and/or any personnel undertaking quality control activities has 
the legal authority to enter premises, request information, take copies of records, and undertake 
other actions required for the correct fulfilment of their quality control duties. This includes the 
power to write formal reports highlighting deficiencies or weaknesses and to take appropriate 
compliance-related corrective or enforcement actions (including issuing directions under the 
authority of the DG, BCAS) when regulated entities are not in compliance with regulations, 
national programs, or entity-approved programme requirements. The legal authority is derived 
by virtue of Paragraph 11.3 of the approved NCASP of the Republic of India and under Rule 58 
of the Aircraft (Security) Rules, 2023. 
 
1.3 Programme operational management: 
 
1.3.1 
The operational management of NCASQCP has been delegated to the DDG, Oversight and 
Compliance (O & C), BCAS by the DG, BCAS. This includes, but is not necessarily limited 
to, the development and maintenance of NCASQCP, as well as the planning, scheduling and 
implementation of quality control activities. The DDG, O & C, BCAS shall submit an annual 
activity schedule and an annual summary report to the DG, BCAS.  
 
1.3.2 
For the purpose of conducting quality control activities, the DG, BCAS, has developed 
guidelines on threat and risk assessment. This includes appropriate matrices, tables, and 
processes for the conduct of threat and risk assessment at the airport level as well as at the 
national level. 
 
 
1.3.3 
It shall be the responsibility of the Oversight & Compliance (O & C) division to provide the 
DG, BCAS with updates and modifications to the NCASQCP. Additionally, O & C division 
shall also be responsible to submit a draft annual schedule of quality control activities and 
annual summary report to the DG, BCAS. The annual summary report shall contain significant 
changes in the overall security status of airports and airport users, a summary of enforcement 
actions initiated (both open and closed), and an analysis of activities and compliance history. 
Furthermore, the O & C division shall project the requirement of the human, material, and 
financial resources for the forthcoming year to the DG BCAS. 
 
1.3.4 
The O & C division has responsibility for day-to-day quality control operations as outlined in 
this programme and the auditor handbook / guide. This includes, but is not necessarily limited 
to, scheduling of activities (audit, inspection, tests), final review of all quality control activity 
reports (audit, inspection and test), review and approval of enforcement action 
recommendations.

1.4.1 Media requests shall be forwarded to the O & C division for consideration. Under no

1.4.2 Enforcement actions initiated by BCAS against regulated entities or individuals are regarded as

authorised by the DG, BCAS. 
 
1.4.3 All data originating from or contained within the NCASQCP, including quality control activity 
reports and outcomes, is considered confidential and may only be disclosed with the explicit 
consent of the DG, BCAS. This includes any news issued to members of the media. 
 
1.5 Handling of sensitive security information: The NCASQCP is a “Sensitive Aviation Security 
Information” document and shall not be disseminated to any person or entity. At a minimum, access 
to the NCASQCP shall be restricted to those persons on “need to know” basis as defined in the 
NCASP, who require such information in the performance of their duties. If special controls are 
required for the protection of information, the degree of protection shall be specified by either the 
originator of the information or the responsible authority. All copies of the NCASQCP shall be 
numbered and any controlled copy that is issued shall be signed. Physical copies of the NCASQCP 
shall be stored securely to prevent unauthorized access. Updates or amendments to the NCASQCP 
shall be disseminated to all authorized programme holders by the DG, BCAS. 
 
1.5.1 All relevant entities responsible for implementing security controls at Indian airports shall ensure 
that individuals acting in their official capacities do not disclose confidential information related 
with an act or attempted act of unlawful interference that could jeopardize the safety of 
international civil aviation. It is the duty of every individual who receives security information 
to ensure that such information is disclosed only to authorised individuals. 
 
1.5.2 All records and reports once completed by an authorized aviation security official relating to 
quality control activities are considered as “Sensitive Aviation Security Information” and may 
only be shared on a confidential basis between the BCAS and the entity that is subject to quality 
control. No entity shall disclose these records or reports without the permission of the DG, 
BCAS.

1.6 Definitions 
Definitions are drawn from a number of sources, including Annex 17, the Aircraft Act, 1934, the 
Aircraft (Security) Rules, 2023, and ICAO Doc 8973 (Aviation Security Manual). The list of 
definitions is not intended to be exhaustive; it is, however, intended to support the common use of

In case of a conflict between the definition mentioned in this document and any legislation of India, 
the legislation shall take precedence. Specific definitions may be included in other documents to

critical observations pertaining to infrastructure and/or equipment must be submitted to

of such critical observations pertaining to infrastructure and/or equipment must be
